channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Harvard-White House Talks Stall, Threatening Quick Settlement
item.description: Harvard University’s talks with the White House have stalled, according to a person familiar with the matter, threatening a quick resolution to a standoff that’s endangering the school’s finances and upending foreign student plans.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: The Lowell House on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Netherlands Delays Decision on TenneT’s German Grid Deal
item.description: The Dutch government needs more time to assess the options for TenneT Holding BV’s German high-voltage business and a decision is likely to come in September.
item.dc:creator: Eyk Henning

media:content.media:description: Cables hang from electricity pylons at the BritNed interconnector, a new 1-gigawatt electricity link between Britain and the Netherlands, operated as a joint venture between National Grid Plc and TenneT Holding BV, near Rochester, U.K., on Thursday, March 24, 2016. A U.K. vote to leave the European Union might force gas and power bills up by 500 million pounds ($700 million) a year, Rudd said on Thursday, warning that a "Brexit" would threaten Britain's energy security.

item.title: Critical Minerals to Top Modi’s Agenda in Five-Nation Tour
item.description: Supply agreements for critical minerals will dominate Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to Ghana, Namibia, Brazil, Argentina and Trinidad & Tobago starting Wednesday as the South Asian country’s industry grapples with restricted supplies from China.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi, India's prime minister, center, during a news conference at Parliament House in New Delhi, India, on Monday, Nov. 25, 2024. Modi will find it increasingly difficult to distance himself from the latest controversy erupting around Gautam Adani, one of the world’s richest businessmen who’s widely seen as having close ties with the Indian leader.

item.title: Transgender-Rights Rulings Warrant New Look, Supreme Court Says
item.description: The US Supreme Court ordered reconsideration of rulings backing transgender rights in clashes over health care and birth certificates, while holding off saying whether the justices will take up a polarizing fight over sports participation in their next term.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: A protester waves a transgender pride flag outside the US Supreme Court in Washington DC, on June 18.

item.title: Harvard Violated Civil Rights of Jews, Trump Officials Say
item.description: The Trump administration said a US investigation found that Harvard University violated civil rights law in its treatment of Jewish and Israeli students, further endangering federal funding for the school.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: The Widener Library on the Harvard Campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Israel Eyes Peace with Syria After Scorning New Government
item.description: Israel expressed openness to peace with Syria, a change of tack after warning against engaging with the new Islamist-rooted government that took power last year.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: A group led by Ahmed al-Sharaa overthrew the long-standing Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad in December.

item.title: Russia Summons Azerbaijani Envoy as Tensions Flare Over Arrests
item.description: Russia summoned Azerbaijan’s ambassador after police in Baku raided the office of a Russian state-funded media outlet amid deteriorating relations between the former Soviet neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Ilya Arkhipov

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Red Square in Moscow.

item.title: Chile Peso Gains as Communist Win Is Seen as a Step Too Far for Left
item.description: Chile’s peso rallied Monday on speculation that a landslide victory for Communist Jeannette Jara in a left-wing presidential primary will make a win for the opposition right in November’s election all the more likely.
item.dc:creator: Philip Sanders

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara at a presidential primary election night rally in Santiago on June 29. Photographer: Cristobal Olivares/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump, Republicans Rush to Overcome Internal Clashes on Tax Bill
item.description: Republican Party leaders are rushing to overcome lingering internal fights over President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending package as Democrats launch attacks to exploit the divisions.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Jamie Tarabay, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Canada Drops Digital Tax That Infuriated Trump to Restart Trade Talks
item.description: Canada withdrew its digital services tax on technology companies such as Meta Platforms Inc. and Alphabet Inc. in a move to restart trade talks with the US.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin, Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and US President Donald Trump. Photographer: Geoff Robins/Getty Images

item.title: Turkish Markets Rally After Key Opposition Case Adjourned
item.description: Turkish markets surged after a court delayed a ruling on a high-stakes case that could unseat the main opposition leader, offering investors a temporary reprieve from mounting political risks.
item.dc:creator: Firat Kozok, Beril Akman, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Ozgur Ozel speaks on stage as attendees hold placards reading "Free Imamoglu" refering to the detention of the Mayor of Istanbul, Ekrem Imamoglu, on the second day of the German Social Democratic Party (SPD) Party Congress in Berlin, on June 28.

item.title: Republicans Agree to Mask $3.8 Trillion of Trump Tax Bill Costs
item.description: Senate Republicans are moving forward with a plan to mask the $3.8 trillion cost of extending expiring tax cuts in President Donald Trump’s signature economic legislation by using an unprecedented accounting maneuver.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Erik Wasson, Chris Cioffi

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Spanish Prime Minister’s Former Top Aide Remanded in Custody
item.description: Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez’s former top adviser was remanded in custody Monday in a corruption probe that could further threaten the embattled Spanish premier’s hold on power.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri, Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Santos Cerdan, arrives at the Supreme Court in Madrid on June 30.

item.title: GOP Gets Supreme Court Review on Political Party Spending Caps
item.description: The US Supreme Court agreed to consider Republican calls to strike down federal caps on the money political parties can spend on advertisements in coordination with congressional candidates.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Supreme Court Rebuffs Bid to Protect Coinbase User Data From IRS
item.description: The US Supreme Court refused to question an Internal Revenue Service summons that forced Coinbase Global Inc. to turn over transaction information for more than 14,000 cryptocurrency customers.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The Coinbase logo on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Wednesday, June 7, 2023. The list of digital tokens deemed as unregistered securities by the Securities and Exchange Commission now spans over $120 billion of crypto after the US agencys lawsuits against Binance Holdings Ltd. and Coinbase Global Inc.

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Cox Appeal in $1 Billion Music Piracy Case
item.description: The US Supreme Court agreed to consider shielding Cox Communications Inc. from a $1 billion lawsuit by the music industry, in a case that could give internet providers new legal protections when users pirate copyrighted works.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: A Cox store in Tucson, Arizona.

item.title: UK Tightens Steel Import Tariff Regime to Fend Off Cheap Imports
item.description: The UK will limit the growth of tariff-free steel imports to guard against a rush of products being redirected from the US.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Rolled steel.

item.title: Moldovan Pro-European Party Leads Poll Before Key Election
item.description: Moldova’s ruling pro-European party is leading in a new opinion poll three months ahead of a general election that’s crucial for maintaining the country’s course to join the European Union by the end of the decade.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Dorin Recean

item.title: Guinea Proposes Extension of Presidential Term to Seven Years
item.description: Guinea’s interim parliament proposed that presidential term limits be extended, months before the country is scheduled to hold elections after four years of military rule.
item.dc:creator: Ougna Camara

media:content.media:description: Members of Parliament attend a session in Port Moresby on April 15.

item.title: Budapest Pride Ban Backfires as Orban Continues Slump in Polls
item.description: The record-breaking turnout at Hungary’s annual Pride march, held in defiance of a police ban encouraged by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, highlighted surging opposition to his 15-year rule.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: Budapest Pride participants cross Elisabeth Bridge on June 28.

item.title: Algeria Jails French Football Reporter for Seven Years
item.description: Algeria jailed a French sports journalist for seven years on charges of “glorifying terrorism,” amid a simmering feud between the North African nation and its former colonial rulers.
item.dc:creator: Souhail Karam, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: JS Kabylie fans.

item.title: Canada Orders Hikvision to Cease Local Operations
item.description: Canadian Industry Minister Melanie Joly said her government ordered Hikvision Canada to cease all operations in the country and close its business.
item.dc:creator: Yi Wei Wong

media:content.media:description: Surveillance cameras manufactured by Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology Co. are mounted on a post at a testing station near the company's headquarters in Hangzhou, China, on Tuesday, May 28, 2019. Hikvision, which is controlled by the Chinese government, is one of the leaders in the market for surveillance technology, with cameras that can produce sharp, full-color images in fog and near-total darkness. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Russia Base Metals Sales to China Surge, Signaling Deep Reliance
item.description: Russian base metals sales to China surged in the first five months of 2025, underscoring its economic dependence on its Asian neighbor even as the country seeks to diversify trade.
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Fedorinova, Andy Lin (News), Julian Luk

media:content.media:description: A worker inspects bound stacks of aluminium ingots ready for shipping at a foundry in Sayanogorsk, Russia. Source: /Bloomberg

item.title: Immigration Hawk Denmark Loosens Rules for Foreign Workers
item.description: Danish companies will get easier access to foreign labor under a plan presented by the government that seeks to balance its harsh anti-immigration stance with the demands of the Nordic nation’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Sara Sjolin

media:content.media:description: Passengers move through Ronald Reagan National Airport.

item.title: Trump Deals Poised to Fall Short of Sweeping Trade Reforms
item.description: With just 10 days to go until President Donald Trump’s country-specific tariffs are set to resume, the White House appears poised to fall short of the sweeping global trade reforms it promised to achieve during the three months they were on hold.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, center, following trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on June 9.

item.title: Rand Strengthens as South Africa’s Coalition Avoids Collapse
item.description: South Africa’s currency gained after the nation’s fractious ruling coalition weathered its latest storm when a key partner opted to remain in the government.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa.

item.title: UK Says Turkey’s Eurofighter Bid Gains Full Consortium Backing
item.description: Turkey’s bid to buy Eurofighter Typhoon jets has won support from all consortium members, the UK said, raising prospects for a deal previously blocked by Germany.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: A Eurofighter Typhoon military jet at the Paris Air Show.

item.title: China Lifts Ban on Japanese Seafood Imports as Frictions Ease
item.description: China has lifted a 2023 ban on imports of seafood from most parts of Japan, removing an irritant in relations with its neighbor by starting to implement a deal reached last September.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Tam, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: A plate of tuna sushi at Yoshitsune sushi restaurant in Urayasu, Japan, on Monday, Dec. 5, 2022. Soaring tuna prices are among the items driving Japan’s fastest inflation in four decades and a fall in purchasing power that are together testing the limits of the country’s outlier policy mix. At Yoshitsune, the days of buying raw tuna are gone as the restaurant buys it frozen to stay on budget.

item.title: Viktor Orban’s Hold on Hungary May Be Slipping
item.description: Budapest just hosted one of the biggest displays of defiance of the Hungarian premier’s 15 years in office.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: People take part in the Pride parade in Budapest, on June 28. Photographer: ATTILA KISBENEDEK/AFP

item.title: Trump Says TikTok Buyer Group Found, Needs China Nod
item.description: President Donald Trump said he has identified a buyer for the US operations of TikTok, the social media app owned by Chinese company ByteDance Ltd., without naming the winning bidder.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: The TikTok app page in the Google Play store on a smartphone arranged in the Queens borough of New York, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. The Supreme Court signaled it's likely to uphold a law that would ban the popular TikTok social media platform in the US if it isn't sold by its Chinese parent company by Jan. 19.
